item.title: Berg’s ‘Wozzeck’ Keeps Shocking Us, After 100 Years
item.description: Alban Berg’s “Wozzeck,” which premiered in the shadow of World War I, will break your heart with a score that captures the essence of opera.
item.dc:creator: Joshua Barone

item.title: Tom Hanks on the Electrifying (and Terrifying) Experience of Writing a Play
item.description: The actor also stars in the Off Broadway production of “This World of Tomorrow,” a yearslong project at the Shed through Dec. 21.
item.dc:creator: Tom Hanks and Thomas Prior
item.media:credit: Thomas Prior for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tom Hanks plays a tech entrepreneur from 2089 who travels back to the 1939 World’s Fair. He said he wanted to explore “lives caught between the certainties of our past and the unknowable future.”

item.title: On ‘SNL,’ Trump Blows Up a Familiar Sleigh
item.description: Josh O’Connor hosted this week’s episode, which satirized an airborne news conference and also featured a pair of very sensitive male strippers.
item.dc:creator: Dave Itzkoff
item.media:description: James Austin Johnson as President Trump, left, and Ashley Padilla as the White House press secretary Karoline Leavitt.

item.title: 41 Things That Stuck With Us in 2025
item.description: Aunt Gladys. Tyler, the Creator. That sex scene in “The Naked Gun.” These are the things Culture staffers couldn’t stop thinking about this year.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: The Real Housewives of Orange County (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Neon; Sara Krulwich/The New York Times; Daniel Arnold, via Loose Joints; Warner Bros.

item.title: The Year Hollywood Finally Confronted Our Political Moment
item.description: In movies like “Eddington,” “Sinners,” “Wake Up Dead Man” and others, filmmakers have at last wrapped their heads around how to explain this period.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)

item.title: Slick Rick Likes His Tea ‘Strong and British’
item.description: “It’s the English side of me that never dies,” said the pioneering wordsmith who is celebrating 40 years of hip-hop classics like “La-Di-Da-Di.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Abrams

item.title: Hanukkah Concerts With Israeli Military Cantor Raise Outcry in Amsterdam
item.description: A concert hall canceled the performance several months ago but then reached a compromise in which three concerts will be held. The bargain hasn’t satisfied critics of the events.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.media:description: Shai Abramson, the chief cantor for the Israeli military, singing in Budapest in January.

item.title: Peter Greene, ‘Pulp Fiction’ and ‘The Mask’ Actor, Dies at 60
item.description: Mr. Greene, who built a four-decade career uncannily portraying villains, was found dead in his apartment in Manhattan on Friday, his manager said.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Desiree Navarro/Everett Collection, via Alamy Stock Photo
item.media:description: Peter Greene in New York in 2010. The New York Times once called his work “scarily authentic.”

item.title: Taylor Swift’s ‘The End of an Era’: 5 Takeaways
item.description: The six-part Disney+ series goes behind the scenes of the pop star’s record-breaking Eras Tour, revealing some of her creative processes and struggles.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.category: The End of an Era (TV Program)
item.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taylor Swift onstage at the opening night of the Eras Tour in March 2023.

item.title: Best Art of 2025
item.description: The art world moved forward with glowing renovations to some of New York City’s cultural jewels, as well as sweeping surveys of ballroom queens, Indigenous artists and more.
item.dc:creator: Holland Cotter
item.category: National Museum of African American History and Culture
item.media:credit: Christopher Gregory-Rivera for The New York Times
item.media:description: Works of African art in the Met’s redesigned Rockefeller wing, which first opened in 1982.

item.title: Tate Museums Are in Choppy Waters. Now, Their Director Is Leaving.
item.description: Maria Balshaw, the director of the British museum group that includes Tate Modern and Tate Britain, is stepping down next spring after nine years in the role.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:description: Maria Balshaw, the director of the Tate museum group, said after her appointment that her aim would be “to ensure that everybody, irrespective of background, feels that they can have a connection to Tate.”

item.title: From ‘Spaghetti Western’ Scores to the Opera Stage
item.description: Throughout his life, Ennio Morricone felt shunned by the classical music world. But these days his pop-culture cachet isn’t such a drawback.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: A rehearsal for Ennio Morricone’s opera, “Partenope,” at the Teatro San Carlo in Naples, Italy. Although the work was composed in the 1990s, it will have its world premiere on Friday.

item.title: At Alvin Ailey, Premieres by Jamar Roberts and Matthew Neenan
item.description: New works by Jamar Roberts and Matthew Neenan had their premieres at Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert

item.title: This ‘Into the Woods’ Is Not That Deep. That’s What Makes It Great.
item.description: A new London staging of the Stephen Sondheim and James Lapine musical makes the most of its comedic elements and delivers a visual treat.
item.dc:creator: Houman Barekat

item.title: ‘Emily in Paris,’ Plus 10 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: The Netflix rom-com series is back for a fifth season, and David Letterman’s interview show returns.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:description: Lily Collins in “Emily in Paris.”

item.title: Rob Reiner, Actor Who Went on to Direct Classic Films, Dies at 78
item.description: Mr. Reiner, who was in “All in the Family,” directed films including “This Is Spinal Tap,” “When Harry Met Sally …,” “The Princess Bride” and “A Few Good Men.”
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.media:description: Rob Reiner in Los Angeles in 1986.

item.title: ‘It: Welcome to Derry’ Season 1 Finale Recap: The Mist
item.description: A strange fog envelops the town, sowing fear and chaos. The monster is loose.
item.dc:creator: Sean T. Collins
item.media:description: Turns out Pennywise (Bill Skarsgard) still has a few tricks up his big pouffy clown sleeve.

item.title: Jeanette Winter, Who Told Children About Artists’ Lives, Dies at 86
item.description: Her picture books found models of perseverance and imagination in figures like Emily Dickinson, Georgia O’Keeffe and Benny Goodman.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub
item.media:description: Jeanette Winter in 2017. She was the writer, illustrator or both of more than 65 children’s books, many of them biographies of great artists.

item.title: ‘Anna Christie’ Review: Michelle Williams on the Waterfront
item.description: The actress stars in Thomas Kail’s luminous revival of Eugene O’Neill’s play about a woman whose past threatens her future.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes
item.media:description: Michelle Williams in the 1921 drama “Anna Christie” at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn.

item.title: Surveillance Never Looked So Good
item.description: Charisse Pearlina Weston turns nefarious materials developed to monitor people into precarious, undulating forms.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Russeth

item.title: Abraham Quintanilla Jr., 86, Dies; Music Producer Steered Daughter Selena’s Career
item.description: As a teenager, he hoped to make it big in the Tejano music world. He realized that dream through his daughter.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: Abraham Quintanilla Jr. in 2017. With his daughter Selena doing vocals, he turned his small family band into a Grammy-winning act, and Selena became known as the queen of Tejano music.

item.title: Stream These 10 Movies and TV Shows Before They Leave Netflix in January
item.description: A ton of titles are expiring soon for U.S. subscribers. Catch them while you can, including a Scorsese classic and one of TV’s most influential series.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey

item.title: Phil Upchurch, Jazz Guitarist and Sideman to Stars, Dies at 84
item.description: A self-taught session man extraordinaire, he played with a constellation of stars, including Michael Jackson, Curtis Mayfield, Chaka Khan and Dizzy Gillespie.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:description: Phil Upchurch in 1983, playing at the North Sea Jazz Festival in The Hague. Although he was known for his versatility across multiple genres, he considered himself a jazz player — albeit one with his own vision.

item.title: Joseph Byrd, Who Shook Up Psychedelic Rock, Dies at 87
item.description: A veteran of the Fluxus art movement, he brought an anarchic spirit to the California acid-rock scene with his band, the United States of America.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.media:description: Joseph Byrd in 1970. He stood apart from his rock music peers as a former ethnomusicology instructor, an authority on early American music and a former student of John Cage, the experimental music titan.

item.title: Joanna Trollope, Popular British Author, Dies at 82
item.description: Her books, many of which were best sellers, often described empty marriages, love affairs (with tasteful sex) and heroic clergymen.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Joanna Trollope after she was made a Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 2019.

item.title: Broadway’s ‘Little Bear Ridge Road,’ With Laurie Metcalf, to Close Early
item.description: The lauded play by Samuel D. Hunter is the first production of Scott Rudin’s comeback season. Despite positive reviews, sales have been soft.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:description: Laurie Metcalf and Micah Stock in “Little Bear Ridge Road,” which is playing at the Booth Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: Watch an Ensemble Scene From ‘Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery’
item.description: The writer and director Rian Johnson narrates a sequence from his film.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy
item.category: Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)

item.title: 6 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include an unexpected holiday adventure and a blockbuster body-swapping comedy.
item.dc:creator: Dina Gachman

item.title: ‘Wake Up Dead Man’ | Anatomy of a Scene
item.description: The writer and director Rian Johnson narrates a sequence from his film.
item.dc:creator: Mekado Murphy
item.category: Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)
item.media:description: Josh O’Connor, left, and Daniel Craig in “Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery.”

item.title: Fleece, Love and Vomit: New Yorkers’ Best (and Worst) SantaCon Stories
item.description: The bar crawl and charity fund-raiser has been eliciting strong reactions in the city for more than 25 years. Readers shared theirs.
item.dc:creator: Callie Holtermann

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel Takes a Swipe at Trump’s ‘Gold Card’
item.description: The new visa for rich foreigners had Kimmel rethinking the Statue of Liberty’s inscription: “Never mind your poor and tired. Give us a million bucks — you’re in.”
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: D.L. Coburn, Playwright With a Sole Hit, ‘The Gin Game,’ Dies at 87
item.description: His two-character work won a Pulitzer Prize and had a long Broadway run, but he never replicated its success and struggled to get his later work staged.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel

item.title: Smithsonian Returns Three Khmer Artifacts Thought Looted to Cambodia
item.description: Museum and Cambodian officials said they jointly investigated the provenance of the objects and found sufficient evidence to suggest they had been stolen.
item.dc:creator: Tom Mashberg

item.title: The Artists Reviving the Legacy of Air Afrique
item.description: Plus: a new Manhattan bathhouse, textiles woven from pineapple leaves and more recommendations from T Magazine.

item.title: ‘Dust Bunny’ Review: A World of Wonders, Familiar and Foreign
item.description: The movie, starring Sophie Sloan and Mads Mikkelsen, is a blast of visual delights.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: U.K. Police Seek Suspects in Theft of Over 600 Artifacts From Museum
item.description: The items were stolen in a “high-value burglary” from the Bristol Museum’s British Empire and Commonwealth collection, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Tess Felder and Alex Marshall

item.title: ‘Afternoons of Solitude’ Looks for Beauty in the Bloodshed of Bullfighting
item.description: Albert Serra’s documentary “Afternoons of Solitude” seeks something transcendent in a tradition that many people, in Spain and elsewhere, find barbaric.
item.dc:creator: Carlos Aguilar
item.media:credit: Elliott Verdier for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Cinema brings you closer to life itself,” Albert Serra said.

item.title: Two Women Who Kept the Art World at Arm’s Length
item.description: Agnes Martin and Jay De Feo spent a lifetime searching for clarity of thought. Their works glow in these two shows.
item.dc:creator: Max Lakin

item.title: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
item.description: A holiday album that cuts through seasonal glut, a late collaboration by Jim McNeely and Helmut Lachenmann’s string quartets are among the highlights.

item.title: ‘Silent Night, Deadly Night’ Review: A Slasher Gets a Giddy Reboot
item.description: This delightfully trashy entry in the seasonal subgenre follows a killer Santa with a heart, and a case of blood lust.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza

item.title: ‘Resurrection’ Review: Bi Gan’s Voyage Into Cinema
item.description: The Chinese director Bi Gan, who has become a lauded fixture on the festival circuit, conjures a boundary-pushing tale that evokes moviemaking itself.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘The King of Color’ Review: He’s Just Into Hue
item.description: In a new documentary, the creator of the Pantone system explains how he standardized colors across the globe.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘Ella McCay’ Review: Right Girl, Wrong Time
item.description: James L. Brooks returns with a lieutenant governor comedy that might leave you more confused than amused.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: In ‘Sunday Without Love,’ Ragnar Kjartansson Plays With Sentiment
item.description: Paradox is at the heart of a new video by the Icelandic artist Ragnar Kjartansson, “Sunday Without Love,” which has its romantic side and undercuts it, too.
item.dc:creator: Blake Gopnik

item.title: ‘Atropia’ Review: No Escape From Reality
item.description: Alia Shawkat and Callum Turner fake it so real in this Army simulation exercise in the California desert.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: Best Comedy of 2025
item.description: Late-night came roaring back to life, Roy Wood Jr. delivered a must-see special and Amy Poehler made a must-listen podcast.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman

item.title: America Wants to Build Again. If You Squint, You’ll See Hopeful Signs.
item.description: Crumbling highways. A housing shortage. Broken infrastructure. America is stuck. But the pendulum may be ready to swing.
item.dc:creator: Michael Kimmelman

item.title: Our Favorite Hidden Gem Books of 2025
item.description: The staff of the Book Review recommends unforgettable books that made our personal best-of-the-year lists.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times Books Staff

item.title: Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 Dominates at the Game Awards
item.description: The role-playing game won nine prizes, including game of the year.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small
item.category: Death Stranding 2: On the Beach (Video Game)

item.title: How Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 Became a Gaming Tour de Force
item.description: Without a blockbuster budget or much experience, the creators of Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 astounded the industry with an emotional narrative and old-school design.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Small

item.title: Late Night Tries to Decipher Another Rambling Trump Speech
item.description: Among other things, President Trump claimed to be a big hit with Black voters. But Desi Lydic says her potato salad is getting better numbers.
item.dc:creator: Trish Bendix
item.category: Late Night with Seth Meyers (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Jon Stewart (TV Program)

item.title: Donald McIntyre, 91, Dies; Starred in New Vision of Wagner’s Operas
item.description: As Wotan in Patrice Chéreau’s neo-Marxist staging of the “Ring” cycle, he was part of a celebrated, polarizing moment in opera history.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Donald McIntyre as Wotan and Gwyneth Jones as Brünnhilde in Wagner’s “Die Walküre” at the Royal Opera in London in 1978. Two years before, Mr. McIntyre had starred as Wotan (alongside Ms. Jones) in a groundbreaking new production of Wagner’s “Ring” operas at the Bayreuth Festival in Germany.

item.title: The President of the Yaddo Artist Retreat Steps Down
item.description: After a quarter century, the Yaddo president Elaina Richardson will step down, having made her mark on the storied arts residency.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.media:credit: Erik Tanner for The New York Times
item.media:description: In her 25 years leading Yaddo, Elaina Richardson has increased the artist residency’s endowment more than fourfold.

item.title: Stephen Downing, Police Officer Who Wrote for TV, Dies at 87
item.description: While serving in the L.A.P.D., he began delivering scripts for series like “Dragnet” and “Adam-12.” After retiring, he was a showrunner for “MacGyver.”
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: ‘Rocky’ Statue to Move to Where It Started: Philadelphia’s Art Museum Steps
item.description: It’s a symbol of the city. But is it art?
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather
item.media:description: Sylvester Stallone with the Rocky statue outside the Philadelphia Art Museum in 2018.

item.title: A Stranger Found Ricki Lake’s Lost Family Photos After L.A. Wildfires
item.description: Patty Scanlon bought a box of snapshots for $20 at a flea market and was stunned to find family photos of Ms. Lake, whose house burned down in January.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

item.title: Sundance 2026 Lineup Includes Charli XCX and Olivia Wilde
item.description: Olivia Wilde will also appear in two films, including one she directed, and the cast of “Little Miss Sunshine” will return for its 20th anniversary.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:description: Charli XCX in “The Moment,” directed by Aidan Zamiri.

item.title: Wendy Osefo Is Among the Latest ‘Real Housewives’ Stars in Legal Trouble
item.description: Osefo, of “The Real Housewives of Potomac,” faces several counts of fraud. She is the latest in a long line of “Housewives” personalities to face legal trouble.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: Wendy Osefo of “The Real Housewives of Potomac” and her husband, Edward Osefo, were indicted on fraud charges in October.

item.title: Charity Raffle Offers a Chance at a Picasso for a $120 Ticket
item.description: A French charity is raffling Picasso’s 1941 portrait “Tête de femme,” valued at more than 1 million euros, for €100 a ticket to raise funds for Alzheimer’s research.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross

item.title: History Colorado Center Rejects Painting, Citing Campaign Finance Law
item.description: A Colorado museum cited state law while rejecting an artwork with unflattering depictions of politicians. Free speech groups called the decision censorship.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi
